page.title: 07 MORPETH CHANTRY
page.content: In the 13th century{John de {Greystock}established a{CHANTRY}where prayers would be said for himself and his family.The chantry priests received alms from travellers for the upkeep of a{bridge}and{school.}The chantry was dissolved by Henry VIII but the{Grammar School}was allowed to continue and was given a{Charter}by{ {Edward VI.}The school remained in the Chantry until 1846 when it moved to Cottingwood Lane.The bridge, having become dangerous, was blown up in 1834 and replaced by the{Telford}Road Bridge but the remaining central pier and two buttresses were later used to support the iron{Swinney}Bridge.The recently restored{CHANTRY}now houses display and conference halls and the{ {Tourist Information}and{Wildlife Trust centres.
